dt: {bc}a cutting tool that consists of a heavy edged head fixed to a handle with the edge parallel to the handle and that is used especially for felling trees and chopping and splitting wood
{bc}a hammer with a sharp edge for dressing {dx_def}see {dxt|dress:1||6e}{/dx_def} or {d_link|spalling|spall:2} stone
{bc}removal from office or release from employment {bc}{sx|dismissal||}

dt.t: Employees with poor evaluations {phrase}got the axe{/phrase}.
Trump quickly {phrase}gave him the ax{/phrase} {gloss}=fired him{/gloss} for his incompetence.

dt: {bc}abrupt elimination or severe reduction of something

dt.t: Unlimited expense accounts, signing bonuses, and office plants—all are {phrase}getting the ax{/phrase} {gloss}=being cut or eliminated{/gloss} thanks to corporate cost-cutting measures.
No party was brave enough to offend its supporters by {phrase}taking an axe to{/phrase} {gloss}=severely reducing{/gloss} expenditure.

dt: {bc}any of several musical instruments (such as a guitar or a saxophone)

dt.t: claims that he has no {it}axe to grind{/it} in criticizing the proposed law

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}æcs{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}ackus{/it} ax, Latin {it}ascia{/it}, Greek {it}axinē{/it}
shortdef: a cutting tool that consists of a heavy edged head fixed to a handle with the edge parallel to the handle and that is used especially for felling trees and chopping and splitting wood
a hammer with a sharp edge for dressing or spalling stone
removal from office or release from employment : dismissal —usually used with the

dt: {bc}to shape, dress {dx_def}see {dxt|dress:1||6e}{/dx_def}, or trim with an axe
{bc}to chop, split, or sever with an axe
{bc}to remove abruptly (as from employment or from a budget)

dt.t: The TV program was {wi}axed{/wi} from the new schedule.

shortdef: to shape, dress, or trim with an axe
to chop, split, or sever with an axe
to remove abruptly (as from employment or from a budget)

dt: {bc}a straight line about which a body or a geometric figure rotates or may be supposed to rotate
{bc}a straight line with respect to which a body or figure is symmetrical
{bc}a straight line that bisects at right angles a system of parallel chords of a curve and divides the curve into two symmetrical parts
{bc}one of the reference lines of a coordinate system {dx_def}see {dxt|coordinate:3||1a}{/dx_def}
{bc}the second vertebra of the neck on which the head and first vertebra turn as on a pivot
{bc}any of various central, fundamental, or axial parts
{bc}one of several imaginary lines assumed in describing the positions of the planes by which a crystal is bounded and the positions of atoms in the structure of the crystal
{bc}a main line of direction, motion, growth, or extension
{bc}an implied line in painting or sculpture through a composition to which elements in the composition are referred

dt.t: fruit and flowers arranged about a diagonal {wi}axis{/wi}

dt: {bc}a line actually drawn and used as the basis of measurements in an architectural or other working drawing

{bc}any of three fixed lines of reference in an aircraft that run in the longitudinal, lateral, and vertical directions, are mutually perpendicular, and usually pass through the aircraft's center of gravity
{bc}a point or continuum on which something centers

et: Middle English, "imaginary line passing through the center of a body, celestial axis," borrowed from Latin, "axletree, axle, chariot, celestial axis," going back to Indo-European {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eḱs-{/it} "axle," whence also, with varying thematic derivation, Germanic {it}*ahsō{/it} (whence Old English {it}eax{/it} "axle," Old Saxon & Old High German {it}ahsa{/it}), Old Russian/Eastern Church Slavic {it}osĭ{/it} "axle," Bosnian-Croatian-Serbian {it}ôs,{/it} Lithuanian {it}ašìs,{/it} Old Prussian {it}assis,{/it} Greek {it}axon-, áxōn,{/it} Sanskrit {it}ákṣaḥ,{/it} Avestan {it}aša-{/it} "armpit"

The Indo-European base {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eḱs-{/it} also has derivatives with a suffixal {it}l,{/it} for which see {et_link|ala|ala}, {et_link|axletree|axletree}; compare also Welsh {it}echel{/it} "axle, pivot," Breton {it}ahel,{/it} which may go back to {it}*akselā.{/it} The various thematic forms and extensions of {it}h{inf}2{/inf}eḱs-{/it} may reflect a root noun rather than an i-stem as in Latin; see E. Hamp, "Refining Indo-European Lexical Entries," {it}Zeitschrift für vergleichende Sprachforschung,{/it} 95. Band, 1. Heft (1981), pp. 81-83. The original meaning of the noun may have been "shoulder joint"—if so, Avestan would be the only language to preserve this sense. It has been suggested that {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eḱs-{/it} was formed by a {ldquo}root extension{rdquo} {it}-s-{/it} from the verbal base {it}*h{inf}2{/inf}eǵ-{/it} "drive (cattle, etc.), set in motion (see {et_link|agent|agent}).
shortdef: a straight line about which a body or a geometric figure rotates or may be supposed to rotate
a straight line with respect to which a body or figure is symmetrical —called also axis of symmetry
a straight line that bisects at right angles a system of parallel chords of a curve and divides the curve into two symmetrical parts

dt: {bc}a broadax formerly used as a weapon of war
{bc}a usually older woman who is sharp-tongued, domineering, or combative

shortdef: a broadax formerly used as a weapon of war
a usually older woman who is sharp-tongued, domineering, or combative

dt: {bc}a short-handled ax intended for use with one hand
{bc}a prehistoric stone tool having one end pointed for cutting and the other end rounded for holding in the hand

shortdef: a short-handled ax intended for use with one hand
a prehistoric stone tool having one end pointed for cutting and the other end rounded for holding in the hand

dt: {bc}a combination pick and adze with a spiked handle that is used in mountain climbing

shortdef: a combination pick and adze with a spiked handle that is used in mountain climbing

dt: {bc}the axis passing through the foci of an ellipse

shortdef: the axis passing through the foci of an ellipse

dt: {bc}an extreme or heavy-handed method of cutting or altering something

shortdef: an extreme or heavy-handed method of cutting or altering something
